bestBHT.bht: Paul's words indicate a previous visit that brought grief. There was mutual pain between Paul and the Corinthians, with both parties grieving each other. While it's uncertain if Paul had already made a second visit, he desired to spare them further sorrow. He resolved to wait for their repentance before coming again, wanting to bring joy rather than grief.

Henry Alford: this refers to what follows: see reff."
this implies, that some former visit had been in grief.
'I grieving you (ver. 2), and you grieving me' (ver. 3): not St. Paul’s grief alone, nor grief alone inflicted on them by St. Paul.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The same antithesis between Paul and them appears in 2 Corinthians 1:23." (Quote 1)
He had warned them 'he would not spare if he should come again.'" (Quote 2)
The 'in heaviness' implies mutual pain; they grieving him, and he them." (Quote 3)
Albert Barnes: I made up my mind on this point; I formed this resolution in regard to my course."
I would not come, if I could avoid it, in circumstances which must have grieved both me and you.
I resolved, therefore, to endeavor to remove these evils before I came, that when I did come, my visit might be mutually agreeable to us both.
Marvin Vincent: Paul, with affectionate tact, puts it as if he had taken this resolution for his own pleasure."
He refers to the sorrow which his coming would bring to the Church.
Again. Referring to a former unrecorded visit.
John Calvin: For now at length the Apostle explains, in what manner he had spared them.
He was unwilling to come to them, lest he should be constrained to grieve them again.
He chose rather to give them longer time for repentance.
Philip Schaff: But I determined this for myself, that I would not come again to you with sorrow."
This is so plainly a continuance of his explanation of the delay of his expected visit to Corinth.
It is a pity a new chapter should in the recognised division have begun here.
Archibald T. Robertson: What does Paul mean by 'again'?...Either interpretation is possible as the Greek stands and scholars disagree.
There is absolutely no way to tell clearly whether Paul had already made a second visit.
If he had done so, it is a bit odd that he did not plainly say so in 2 Corinthians 1:15 when he is apologizing for not having made the proposed visit.
John Gill: That he would not come with sorrow and heaviness, bewailing their sins not repented of, and by sharp reproofs and censures, which in such a case would be necessary, be the cause of grief and trouble to them."
He determined to wait their repentance and amendment before he came again.
As his first coming among them was to the joy of their souls, so it was a determined case with him, that his second coming should not be with grief, either to them or himself, or both.
John Wesley: In grief — Either on account of the particular offender, or of the church in general.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse seems to refer to the grief that had been caused by a previous visit from Paul. There is an antithesis between Paul and the Corinthians, with both sides feeling sorrow and grieving each other. Paul had warned them that he would not spare them if he were to come again, but he tactfully puts it as if he made the resolution for his own pleasure. It's unclear whether Paul had already made a second visit, as scholars disagree on the interpretation of again. Nevertheless, Paul wanted to avoid coming to them with sorrow and heaviness, desiring to give them more time for repentance and amendment before his next visit.

Paul's words in 2 Corinthians 2:1 allude to a previous visit that had caused grief. His relationship with the Corinthians was marked by mutual pain, with both sides grieving each other. While it's unclear whether Paul had already made a second visit, it is evident that he wanted to spare them and himself from further sorrow. He resolved to wait for their repentance and amendments before coming again, desiring a visit that would bring joy rather than grief.

Paul's words indicate a previous visit that brought grief. There was mutual pain between Paul and the Corinthians, with both parties grieving each other. While it's uncertain if Paul had already made a second visit, he desired to spare them further sorrow. He resolved to wait for their repentance before coming again, wanting to bring joy rather than grief.

Paul, with affectionate tact, refers to a former unrecorded visit that had brought mutual pain to both him and the Corinthians. He had already warned them of his uncompromising stance and that he would not spare them if he were to come again. This resolution was made to spare them from sorrow and heaviness, giving them more time for repentance. His intention was not to grieve them again but to bring joy to their souls. His aim was to wait for their repentance and amendment before making another visit, ensuring that his second coming would not be a cause of grief to either party.

Paul, with affectionate tact, refers to a former unrecorded visit that had brought mutual pain to both him and the Corinthians. He had already warned them of his uncompromising stance and that he would not spare if he were to come again. His resolution was made to spare them from sorrow and heaviness, giving them more time for repentance. His aim was to wait for their amendment before making another visit, ensuring that his second coming would not be a cause of grief to either party.
